displayed_text: Patient: Right. So, I mean, as I said, I prefer to, to, to keep that to the last option, chemotherapy. Just because of, uh, how draining it is. Doctor: Right. Patient: B_, and my presumption is, if I stay with what I’m doing, that the PSA will continue to rise. As long as it continues to rise, it seems, um, with all the drugs I’ve had, it keeps going up. Doctor: Correct. So, when we did all the research with Enzalutamide, uh, patients on those studies stayed on treatment until either one of two things happened. Patient: Um Hmm. Doctor: They felt worse and the, because of the cancer or the scan showed new disease. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, that’s where we’re sort of in this legal stuff. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, it’s not that I think that (Zytiga) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? And, I can’t.

Family Member 1: I’ll call. Doctor: Yeah. All right. Family Member 1: So did W___ then tell you that he's been getting these cramps in his legs? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Okay, that and then number two, he did say you know, his gums are real sensitive, but he never told me. Patient: Oh no, no, no. That was when I was taking the Elida. Doctor: Yep. Patient: Or when I would I brush my teeth. Doctor: Yep. Yep. So is it better now on the medicine? Patient: It’s gone. Family Member 1: So that might happen with this pill now, right? Or we don't know? Doctor: We don't know, anything is possible, but most of it is, you know, it's going to be very cyclical, right? Patient: Right.

Family Member 1: And so like, now when he starts chemo or whatever and if he gets nauseous, I call M____? Doctor: Exactly. Yep. And you know, we'll make sure you have your prescription or whatever. Well, hopefully we'll have to give it to you so that, you know, when people run into trouble, it's always at 2 AM in the morning, right? Family Member 1: Right? Doctor: When you're like, “Uh oh, nowhere to go and no one to call.” So, first of all, you'll have that in your medicine cabinet. We'll make sure you have your nausea medication, because that's usually the thing that runs into trouble. You know, if you have diarrhea or constipation, that's over the counter that you can get, go to any 24 hour pharmacy for that. Family Member 1: Okay, yeah. Doctor: But things that are nausea medicines require prescriptions. Family Member 1: Do you do Zofran? Doctor: We do Zofran and we do Compazine. And then depending on the level of how much nausea you know. Family Member 1: Zofran works for me. I got pneumonia. Doctor: Well, you're right. And I think the important part here is that this is not a big nausea, type of chemo. There are some where you're like, “Okay, brace yourself, it's going to happen.” This is pretty mild. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It's actually called a mild emetogenic. So it just means it’s not gonna make you puke, but everybody's different.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: But in combination they need to see how the drug levels behave. Patient: How many days will I have to be there? Doctor: I think there are two long days, but you’ll have the full schedule of how often you have to come in. Family Member: So this is a different clinical trial. Is it a clinical trial? Doctor: Different than the one he’s on. Yes. Family Member: Yeah so we’d be on two clinical trials? Doctor: Well this one you’ll just be in follow-up. You won’t be actively on this particular one. Family Member: So the Xtandi… Doctor: So you’ll be off active treatment from our current clinical trial because you’ve progressed technically. Patient: So I wouldn’t be part of that clinical trial? Doctor: You’d still be part of it for follow-up reasons but not actively on. So you wouldn’t get the Xtandi from this particular clinical trial Family Member: Yeah.

Patient: Really? Doctor: Yeah. I don’t see any reason to cancel that. Family Member: Unless you want to – so it doesn’t matter whether we sign the consent today or that day to you. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So when’s the next time I come in to I guess there? There’s no way of doing it here? Doctor: It’s too much. Family Member: I think it’s a echocardiogram… Healthcare Professional: Phase I. Patient: Can I bring a book? Doctor: Oh yeah, yeah. They even have movies and they have a TV there. Family Member: You’re gonna bring me too. I’m definitely coming to this. Doctor: They have all kinds of stuff to do there.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Post high school training other than col: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Post high school training other than college (vocational or technical)

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Healthcare Professional: Yeah, good idea. Doctor: I just wont go there. Healthcare Professional: How old is she? Family Member 1: Yeah but the Mother is. Doctor: Yeah, but they’re always into things and we talked about this. Family Member 1: She’s not out of her first trimester. Yeah. Family Member 3: So um, we are worried about him being around the mother that is newly pregnant, she gets her first ultrasound right now. So what do you think? Doctor: Well, they're, you know- Family Member 1: If they ask us for dinner. Doctor: Yeah, I mean, it's sort of you know, you're you're just having social contact is okay. Family Member 1: It’s okay. So he could be around them. Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Right. Doctor: But, and it’s also a drug that if you take it long-term, you can get side effects from it, in terms of immune system. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: People tend to, you know, it tends to pop your appetite up, so you feel like you want to eat more. Patient: Give me the glasses. Doctor: It can also affect your skin. Some people, their skin gets very thin, and they bruise easily, particularly at the higher doses. So we, we could try the other one. I, I mean- Family Member: But you feel that would be less tiresome-? Doctor: Well, I just tell you my global experience with both drugs. Doctor: Has been it seems like both of them has a side effect, fatigue. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But my experience with using both drugs now, it seems like it’s a little bit more with the Xtandi. Uh, and the other question is, you know, we do have a couple of trials of Xtandi, uh, that, uh, I don’t know if you’re interested in going on another trial at this point. (Sound Door opens)

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So again, you have my blessing, so to speak, but I would also like a second person’s approval as well. Patient: Right. Doctor: Given the primary care provider who’s known you for a long time Patient: Right. Yeah, share it with my primary care, Dr____. Doctor: Now your PSA level from two weeks ago, I think it was third. Patient: Two months, two weeks, yeah. Doctor: Was at zero point five. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay, so that’s very good news because it’s a very slight - Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it was zero point three. The time before that it was like two months before and went from point three to point five. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: So, a lot of people are different in their activity level. You know, some folks are just go, go, go, and some are like Patient: RIght. Doctor: oh, no, I like to chill and be on my computer and watch my TV and get on the phone, you know, so everyone’s activity level. Patient: I like more activity. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But it’s harder for me Doctor: Yeah. Patient: because it brings me down because the next day I can’t do nothing, you know. Doctor: Exactly. Patient: And I don’t like that. Doctor: Yeah. This is common.

Family Member: He’s scheduled today. Doctor: Oh you’re scheduled today, yes. Patient: One o’clock. Doctor: So you’ll get that today but we generally start the, we have to put in for the Zytiga to get approved; we have to put in the chemo to get approved. It takes a couple of weeks to do all that. So we would start all of that sort of in you know mid-January. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Family Member 1: Yeah, I don’t have any additional questions. Doctor: Great. Patient: There you go. Thank you. Family Member: I have a very basic question. Doctor: Of course. Family Member: What does cure mean?

Patient: No. Doctor: Holding his own, getting worse, better? Family Member: I think he’s basically holding his own. Family Member 1: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. And I see you still use a cane? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Anything new on your body you want me to take a look at? Bumps, lumps? Patient: Yeah. Since you took, you said that. Right, huh, huh, huh, right there. It feels like a, a scab. But then sometimes it feels like a, a needle. Doctor: But you can pinpoint it to the one place? Patient: Yep. Doctor: That’s a little dry skin there. Okay. Patient: And then you scratch it- Doctor: Anything else to look at? Any swelling or anything?

Family Member: In January. Doctor: So if you’ve already got an appointment for January – Family Member: January thirty. Doctor: Yeah, that will be your next shot. So typically I schedule that no matter what. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’re always going to come in and see me or (says name) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. And the chemo is what we’re here to talk about today- Patient: Okay. Doctor: It is you know if you’re still interested in the clinical trial, have questions for me about the clinical trial, then I’m going to bring D___ in. So she’s the research nurse that I’ll sort of is it doable, can we get started, and what you have to do to go forward, okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then once you guys sign the paperwork and we move forward, then you and I will pick a date to pick the day the chemo starts. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: it was like oh, no you kind of had these bits and pieces, Patient: Right. Doctor: one, your insurance won’t approve it and number two it’s the wrong treatment. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, if that’s sort of gone and nowhere to be found on this CAT scan then I think radium is it. Now, radium does two things. One is that it helps you live longer but also helps with pain so those people who are, you know, whether you’re taking a Tylenol over-the-counter or you’re taking actual narcotics that should improve. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, all the new studies are like hey, radium and phone a friend, you know, radium and Xtandi, radium and chemo, radium and whatever. So, they’re all in studies but not standard of care yet. I’m gonna pause right there and see how you guys are doing. This is not a test. There’s no test. No test. Family Member: Okay, he was asking when we were waiting for you. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If the treatment you’re going to give him is going to make him feel better Patient: Yes. Family Member: or is he still gonna feel fatigued and miserable.

Patient: Right, right, exactly. Doctor: They don’t need a doctor to do it. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, huh. Patient: Right. Doctor: So. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I made a copy for you so you can, um, this, this has a pretty good amount of information. Family Member: We get to keep this? Doctor: Yeah. It’s yours – it’s all, it’s in our computer. Family Member: So, keep the appointments that we have already? Like the hormone shot in January. Doctor: Yes.

Family Member: So continue with the Lupron, and every four months is what she gets us. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So what’s, what’s the deal at the (coughs) Doctor: Well, the trial is done. They are still analyzing the results. So there’s no final results, yet. Patient: From what? Doctor: From the study you were on. Right? That’s what you’re asking? Patient: No. What I- you’re looking if I can get on it. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: You’re looking at clinical trials, I guess. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. I see. So, yeah, so that one is an option for you especially now that the PSA is going up slightly. If you want to do it, that is an option. Patient: What is it? Doctor: Okay. So what it is, is it’s a radiation, a type of radiation that you would get, but it’s tagged to something called PSMA.
